Posts.Content: Hello Cuppatime I am in similar position to you. I am on Dr Reddys for some time now and a local pharmacy has a stash with my name on. When they ran out some time ago I contacted the distributor and explained the situation. Following day I received call from the pharmacy saying he had managed to get some. ( I dont know who contacted whom). My pharmacy is a local independent and well known in the area for helping people out, I do have some side effects but they are definitely bearable. I even notice slight changes when the batch number changes, The trouble is Letrozole messes with your system but because we have to take it we soldier on. I have started to have reactions / intolerance to  other stuff e.g. milk, sugar, processed foods and some wines.  Kept me off the junk food at Christmas and now I have lost the taste for it and dont get tempted with stuff the family expect. Good luck  BIG HUG Cathy
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hello Cuppatime I am in similar position to you. I am on Dr Reddys for some time now and a local pharmacy has a stash with my name on. When they ran out some time ago I contacted the distributor and explained the situation. Following day I received call from the pharmacy saying he had managed to get some. ( I dont know who contacted whom). My pharmacy is a local independent and well known in the area for helping people out, I do have some side effects but they are definitely bearable. I even notice slight changes when the batch number changes, The trouble is Letrozole messes with your system but because we have to take it we soldier on. I have started to have reactions / intolerance to  other stuff e.g. milk, sugar, processed foods and some wines.  Kept me off the junk food at Christmas and now I have lost the taste for it and dont get tempted with stuff the family expect. Good luck  BIG HUG Cathy
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hi  I didnt actually fast but I did cut out any fatty food for 48 hours before my chemo. I also made a point of drinking as much water as I could so that my body could flush everything through efficiently. I did seem to have a better ride than some of the others around me.   A friend is having chemo at the mo and has tried fasting and has said she things it works for her. Its certainly worth a go. Take care  Big hug Cathy
Posts.Title: Is anyone trying FASTING (restricting Calories) before chemo to reduce...

Posts.Content: Hello All I have to agree that her comment about BC being doable was insensitive. I have been off work for 1 year and have only just finished my Herceptin course after having MX, chemo and rads. I am really struggling with the SE of letrozole and hoping to return to work after Christmas.  What message has this send out to our employers and work colleagues. When I have meetings at work to discuss my time off and see my colleagues they comment on how well I look, but it is so difficult explain the fatigue, joint pains and sleepless nights. If any have seen VDs first blog they will think I've been on holiday. Surely during her career as a journalist she must have interviewed someone with cancer before? Or even a friend? The only reason we have done the doable is because we had no alterative.  Big hugs to all Cathy
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi Suzie Just noticed your post and would like to pass on my own tips on dealing with chemo. During the 48 hours prior to treatment don't eat fatty food and drink lots of water so your body can flush things through quickly Drink water all the time Buy a child's toothbrush and rinse under warm water to protect gums and mouth Have lots of tins of soup or baked beans in cupboard. No matter how bad you feel you have to eat something. I would heat up a teacup of beans and eat one a time with teaspoon. You do feel better with something inside you. Eat well. It keeps your bloods up and you will feel better as a result. Chemo wardrobe. Leggings and floppy t-shirts  Do as much as you can yourself. You will feel better but ask for help when you need it. Good luck Big hug  Cathy xxx
Posts.Title: tips to reduce side effects before starting chemo, please

Posts.Content: Hi Thank you for your comments. I am afraid letrozole is really affecting me badly. I tend to be a candy floss pink ( to which everyone comments on how rosy my cheeks look) a lot of the time. Its a conversation stopper to anyone I am talking to. They just seem to stare at me wondering what is going on. I look like a menopausal woman having a panic attack. I wanted to move on and the group I worked amongst were aware and carried on as normal when I flush. I may have to return to work with an elbow crutch due to the letrozole side effects and existing arthritis. I am feeling self conscious and vulnerable. I am moving to a dept that has a high staff turnover. There is nothing on my CV similar to the role I am being placed in. In truth I am feeling cast aside and regretting my decision to return under these circumstances, Cathy
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: Hi can anyone give me some advice. I cheerfully announced to my employers that I felt I was ready to return to work on a phased basis. However I have been advised that I am to move to a new dept into a call centre type role. My previous role was as an analyst of documents and whilst responsible and quiet autonomous role. I will be working close to my old dept but not with them. The women who I used to work with are aware of my treatments and the difficult side effects of my letrozole. I based my decision to return to work based on the role I thoroughly enjoyed and support of the women around me.  I have gone into meltdown panicking. I don't know the role or people surrounding me. The old team have been good as gold about keeping their distance when they have colds etc and reassuring me they will look after me.The new team will just know I've had cancer but now I am back. I won't even be having lunch with my former colleagues. How do I explain letrozole side effect to a 20ish year old man when I flush. I can't sleep so tiredness is increasing the flushes and aches and pains. I am distraught. Please does anyone have some advice. Thank you Cathy
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: Oh Ali So sorry to hear you are having problems. I know you hate needles so this must be a nightmare for you. Hope it improves. Big hug. Cathy xx
Posts.Title: pic line trouble

Posts.Content: Hi Nettie We all have questions and never feel guilt about asking them. I cant provide the answer to your question today but someone will be able to help. I have a A5 note book that I jot down questions and any info I an given at appointments. Having questions and any possible answers to hand before your appointment will help you absorb and info you are given. Being prepared is one bit of control you can have in this situation.  Do you have anyone to go with you? Good Luck  Cathy
Posts.Title: Questions about Oncology appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy  I was in the same boat as you 2 weeks ago. Go your local chemist and ask to see the pharmacist and explain your situation. I was given difflam to numb my sore throat, extra strong pastilles. Get some mouth alcohol free mouth wash, berocca and a thermometer, take paracetamol for any fever and stay away from anyone slightly ill.I changed my bed daily and left church early because someone sat behind me with stinking cold to reduce any risk of my cold progressing or developing. It worked and I had my 1st session as planned on the Monday. I had informed the hospital and they checked my white count to confirm I was ok for treatment even though my throat still felt a bit rough. Good luck Cathy
Posts.Title: Chemo starting Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi I have only been on letrozole 15 months and have found a certain brand suits me. However I have found a slight change when opening a new prescription if it is a different manufactured batch. There is a ref no on each pack.  The hot weather affected me recently and any stress makes a difference. No two days appear the same Good luck  Cathy
Posts.Title: Letrazole - side effects after four years

Posts.Content: Hi Rhonda Yes. I am 3 months post chemo but still having 3weekly herceptin infusion. On my last session I developed a rash on my chest and got a bit wheezy. Thinking I was reacting to herceptin I was dosed with hydrocortisone and pirton by IV. Next day I still had rash but also another similar one in crease of my elbow. I have developed allergy to the sterile wipe and sticking plaster. Just have my next dose of herceptin but have to be dosed with piriton and hydrocortisone. It's laughable that after all the toxins pumping into us that a wipe and sticking plasters are causing problems. Hey ho   Cathy
Posts.Title: New Allergies

Posts.Content: Hi Linz I am afraid independence goes out the window sometimes. It wasn't until I was so ill that my husband had to take over and learn to do a lot more that I relaxed. We feel awful and any stress makes it worse. Having to juggle a home is stressful enough even if it is only the voices in your head listing all the things that  need doing. I'm afraid as the song says "Let it go" you need to keep your strength up. As Dreamthief says there are times when you can get out a bit and take advantage of it and make plans with people who will look after you and understand if any plans go pearshape. I am through my chemo now but remember being able to do enough to not feel frustrated. However hand over the smaller things to someone else if you can. ( Even shopping on line will save you from the tall sweaty man coughing all over me in a supermarket queue - you can't escape when all your stuff is on the belt and caught in the queue.) I went blue trying not to breathe in! Enjoy what you can in the meantime. It will make you laugh when you look back on your own coping strategies later. Good luck and of course BIG HUG. Cathy
Posts.Title: Chemo advice please

Posts.Content: Hello Is work causing the stress or are you stressed about the cancer? Cathy
Posts.Title: Stress at work after cancer

Posts.Content: Hi All My bloods are tomorrow and so far feel well so I was hopeful. Unfortunately on Sunday popped to supermarket and was coughed all over by sweaty man behind me at checkout. Couldn't get away. We was coughing and huffing a puffing behind me. I could feel his breath on me! All I could do was put my head down away from him and put my hood up on jacket. Wiped my face and hands with gel as soon as I could. Fingers crossed. But what a idiot.  Ali Good luck with needle phobia. Remember to try and relax. Shake out your arms to release tension, do some jumping jacks if you can. Nurses won't mind and humour breaks tension. Another tip is as they are doing anything you don't like count to 10 and wriggle your toes. The needles are very sharp(sorry) and if you can relax it really won't hurt. I used to be terrified and something happened many years ago when I needed lots of needles. A nurse helped with this technique and I am fine now but remember what it feels like. Cathy
Posts.Title: Thursday chemo club

Posts.Content: Hello. I am 15 months into my journey so have had several crawling up the wall with anxiety moments but last June I joined a mindfulness group and something just clicked in my brain. Worrying about the result won't change that result. Admittedly when I have my appointment for the result  I want to snatch the paper from his hand before he reads it and my husband can be a bit jumpy in the waiting room. If the result is the worst it can be you are about to be very busy. Don't waste the time whilst you waiting.Get busy.  Do stuff anything, feed ducks, have nights out anything but don't brood. There was so much stuff I couldn't do after diagnosis, even go to church!!!!
Posts.Title: Waiting for results a nightmare

Posts.Content: Hello Cycling Girl Sorry but I had to smile when I saw your comment about slowing down. I'm afraid there will be days when you cant get going. But always keep some internal batteries to keep you going. Remember when you went out as a teenager but had to keep the bus fare to get home!  I am 3 & half year since chemo but had to continue with herceptin until November 2015. I worked hard to maintain my blood results so that chemo could go ahead on time through a rich iron diet. It will also help with any fatigue. There isnt much you can control throughout this process but doing as you are told is a good start. At least if there is a problem you can say you have done your best. EG doing you physio and did I mention DRINK WATER. I used to fill up on water and avoid fatty food for the 2 days prior to treatment so your liver can flush everything through quicker. I had a chemo wardrobe leggings etc. Get out of bed in the morning, get dressed then rest on sofa if needed. I set myself a 9.00 deadline to get up.  Join a support group through hospital if there is one. I truely believe this helped me. We had Xmas Do, coffee mornings etc. gets you out with like minded people as sometime "outsiders" just wont get it!  This is not normal, dont expect life to be normal for the next few months I'm afraid but dont just wait for it to be over. Live through it as best you can. Biggest hug.  By the way did I mention DRINK WATER!!!!! Cathy
Posts.Title: How to deal with chemo explosion

Posts.Content: Hi  Before you give up on Letrozole try another brand. I use sun pharm brand and can live with the side effects on it. Rough at times but give it a go Cathy
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Hi  Saw your post and had to reply. your first chemo is tricky. Not only are you having chemo but you are still dealing the shock of diagnosis. You will never feel the way you do at your first chemo again because of all the unknowns that you have been through. Now I am not saying it is easy from here but now you know the team and they will know you. Without the fear of the first time you will feel more in control. Remember your first driving lesson - you thought you would never master it.  Look after yourself - never before have you have licence to treat yourself well. You and getting through this is your new priority! Prepare yourself for the next session but dont dwell on it. Make yourself comfortable. You have to take care of yourself. It is important to eat and drink lots of water to flush the treatment through. My secret was tins of beans. No matter how rough eat something. Put half tin of beans in mug, microwave and eat with a spoon. This is simple way of looking after yourself and you feel better if you can control something in the chaos.  Plan to do things during your well week. Shop on line (supermarkets are full of sneezing /coughing people). Watch films, read books. As I say unfortunately you are where you are and will have to continue. Speak to counsellors, get all the advice and imfo you want. We are here to help. Do whatever it takes to make this comfortable for you. The more I did for myself the more it helped as I knew at least I was trying.  Good luck  Big hug Cathy xxxx
Posts.Title: How to deal with chemo explosion

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone I am 9 months on from diagnosis had my mx finished chemo, rads and now just on the heceptin and aromatose inhibitors. A fews weeks ago I posted that I was acting like a 2 year old due the stress of EVERYTHING no matter what it was. I asked for some counselling and before I had my first session I popped into a mindfulness course run by Meetup. I have changed in ways that I cant believe. Whilst doing reading about the subject I read something along the lines of worrying about something wont change the result. I know we have all be told this before but on this occasion it was  like a light bulb moment. I have actually chilled! Even people I went to school with a very long time ago would never think this possible. I have a PET scan on Monday and yes I have my concerns regarding a niggley cough and a sore rib but worrying will not change the result of my scan. 3 weeks ago I was crawling up the wall with stress about this scan! I love the new me. Speak to anyone you can. Big Hug we all need one  XXXXXXXX Cathy
Posts.Title: Struggling on the inside
